summary: This document is a legal opinion by French attorney William Julie regarding French extradition law, prepared for Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team. It analyzes whether France would extradite Maxwell (a French citizen) to the U.S. if she fled there while on bail, concluding extradition is legally permissible and likely. The opinion includes an affidavit from Maxwell waiving her right to contest extradition.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in U.S. criminal case, charged with involvement in sexual activities with Jeffrey Epstein and minor girls. She is a citizen of the U.S., U.K., and France, and the opinion assesses her potential extradition from France.

persons.name: William Julie
persons.role: Attorney at law, author of opinion
persons.context: French attorney who authored the legal opinion on French extradition law at the request of Olivier Laude, acting for Maxwell's U.S. counsel.

persons.name: Olivier Laude
persons.context: French lawyer who instructed William Julie to draft the opinion on behalf of Cohen & Gresser LLP, counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP, U.S. counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, mentioned in her affidavit.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP, U.S. counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, mentioned in her affidavit.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Judge before whom Ghislaine Maxwell signed her affidavit and waiver of extradition.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual with whom Ghislaine Maxwell allegedly facilitated sexual activities with minor girls.

connections.description: William Julie was hired by Maxwell's legal team to provide a legal opinion on French extradition law for her defense.
Olivier Laude, acting for Cohen & Gresser LLP, instructed William Julie on behalf of Maxwell.
Mark S. Cohen is listed as U.S. counsel for Maxwell, with whom she reviewed the charges.
Christian R. Everdell is listed as U.S. counsel for Maxwell, with whom she reviewed the charges.
The document references Maxwell's alleged role in sexual activities between Jeffrey Epstein and minor girls.

events.title: Bail Hearing for Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Bail hearing where U.S. government argued Maxwell posed a flight risk due to her French citizenship, claiming France would not extradite its citizens. Bail was denied.

events.title: Superseding Indictment Filed
events.description: Superseding Indictment SI 20 Cr. 330 (MN) filed against Ghislaine Maxwell, containing grand jury charges.

events.title: Execution of Extradition Waiver
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell signed an affidavit and waiver of extradition, irrevocably waiving her right to contest extradition from France to the U.S.

events.title: Extradition Treaty Signed
events.description: Extradition Treaty between the United States of America and France signed in Paris.

locations: Metropolitan Detention Center, Brooklyn, New York
keyFacts: The legal opinion concludes that France can legally extradite its own citizens to the U.S. under the existing Extradition Treaty, which contains no prohibition, contrary to the U.S. government's claim at Maxwell's bail hearing.
Ghislaine Maxwell executed an irrevocable waiver of her right to contest extradition from France to the U.S., intended to be used if she fled to France after release on bail.

The opinion states that if Maxwell fled to France in violation of bail, it is highly likely she would be placed in custody there and that French authorities would likely grant extradition due to her U.S. citizenship, the waiver, and diplomatic considerations.
The document analyzes French extradition procedure, noting that if a person consents to extradition, the judicial process can be completed within approximately 14 working days after arrest.

The opinion clarifies that the principle against extraditing nationals is not a constitutional rule in France and is superseded by treaties like the one with the U.S., making extradition of a French citizen legally permissible.
